body:
Hi @ati6868, at the moment, it makes no sense to connect to a layer of `Input` nodes, they simply discard their input. `Input` nodes spikes are set by the user by passing them to `network.run(inputs=...)`.

You could instead create a network with a layer of `Input` nodes (A), connected to a layer of `LIFNodes` (B), which is recurrently connected to itself, or connected to a third layer of `LIFNodes` (C) which connects back to B.

It might be good to support adding support for your use case, though; I'll look into it.

thank you @djsaunde  for your response . my model is supposed to use predictive coding that's why i need to use feedback connections for propagating predictions of lower layers generated by upper layers . 
if it's not possible , Could i have two layers of `LIFNodes` instead of " one layer of `Input` nodes and one layer of `LIFNodes` " , while i need to use mnist images for my model?
i mean is that possible that first layer is `LIFNodes` that receives mnist images and second layer is a `LIFNodes` too and then it connects from second layer to first layer?

No, that wouldn't work either, since inputs to `LIFNodes` can't be provided by passing them to `network.run(...)`; they are generated during the simulation.

I will look into refactoring the `Input` nodes to support your use case.

@ati6868 That should work. Just set the weights from layer1 to layer2 as `torch.ones(784, 784)`. so the spikes are unmodified and are simply transmitted.

I will try it 👍
I think for one to one connection you want `torch.eye(784)` instead of `torch.ones(784, 784)`

issue.title: Refactoring Input nodes to support incoming connections; removing RealInput nodes (subsumed by Input nodes); adding support for input to arbitrary layers.

repository.name: bindsnet
repository.description: Simulation of spiking neural networks (SNNs) using PyTorch.

issue.body:
This PR is a little tricky, so I don't expect it to get merged right away. Addresses use cases discussed in #332 and #333. Namely, this adds support for:

- Incoming connections to `Input` nodes that do something. `Input` nodes now use input from incoming connections instead of discarding it in favor of what's passed by `network.run(inputs=...)`. NB: users have to be a bit more careful with data types in this situation.
- The output of `Input` nodes can now have any type; this subsumes the `RealInput` nodes class, which has been removed as a result.
- Any kind of node can take input passed to `network.run(inputs=...)`. For example, you can create a network with only `LIFNodes` (no `Input` nodes), and inject input directly to them.
